The '''Legal Services Corporation''' ('''LSC''') is a publicly funded, [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit corporation]] established by the [[United States Congress]]. It seeks to ensure equal access to justice under the law for all Americans by providing funding for civil [[legal aid in the United States|legal aid]] to those who otherwise would be unable to afford it. The LSC was created in 1974 with bipartisan congressional sponsorship and the support of the [[Nixon administration]], and is funded through the congressional appropriations process.
LSC has a board of eleven directors, appointed by the [[President of the United States]] and confirmed by the [[United States Senate]], that set LSC policy. By law the board is bipartisan; no more than six members can come from the same party.<ref name="lsc-board">{{cite web | url=http://www.lsc.gov/about/board.php | title=Board of Directors Profiles | publisher=Legal Services Corporation | accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> LSC has a president and other officers who implement those policies and oversee the corporation's operations.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lsc.gov/about/office_president.php | title=Office of the President | publisher=Legal Services Corporation | accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref>
For Fiscal Year 2015, LSC had a budget of $375 million to fund civil legal aid. LSC is the largest single funder of civil legal aid in the country, distributing more than 90 percent of its total funding to 134 independent nonprofit legal aid programs.<ref name="2013 budget">{{cite web|title=LSC Funding {{!}} LSC – Legal Services Corporation: America's Partner for Equal Justice|url=http://www.lsc.gov/congress/lsc-funding|publisher=Legal Services Corporation|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref>
== History == ===Background=== LSC is one of the organizational descendants of the former [[Office of Economic Opportunity]] (OEO).<ref name="brock-96">{{cite book | last=Brock | first=David | authorlink=David Brock | title=[[The Seduction of Hillary Rodham]] | publisher=[[Free Press (publisher)|The Free Press]] | year=1996 | isbn=0-684-83451-0}} pp. 96–97.</ref> The [[Economic Opportunity Act of 1964]], a key part of President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]'s [[Great Society]] vision, established the OEO. From 1965 on, starting with a budget of $1 million,<ref name="brock-96"/> the OEO created 269 local legal services programs around the country,<ref name="time072875">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913362,00.html | title=Corporation for the Poor | publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' | date=1975-07-28 | accessdate=2009-02-03}}</ref> such as [[California Rural Legal Assistance]],<ref name="time072875"/> which made a name for themselves suing local officials and sometimes stirring up resentment against their federal funding.<ref name="time072875"/>
By the early 1970s the [[Nixon administration]] began dismantling the OEO; funding for legal services for the poor began to wither, and supporters looked for an alternative arrangement.<ref name="time072875"/> In 1971 a bipartisan congressional group, including Senators [[Ted Kennedy]], [[William A. Steiger]], and [[Walter Mondale]], proposed a national, independent Legal Services Corporation;<ref name="nyt031871">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/03/18/archives/bipartisan-group-in-congress-urges-a-legal-services-corporation-for.html| title=Bipartisan Group in Congress Urges a Legal Services Corporation for the Poor | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1971-03-18 | accessdate=2008-02-03 | format=fee required}}</ref> at the same time, administration officials such as Attorney General [[John N. Mitchell]] and chief domestic advisor [[John Ehrlichman]] were proposing their own somewhat similar solution.<ref name="nyt031871"/>
===Creation and the Ford era=== The idea behind the LSC was to create a new corporate entity that would be funded by Congress but run independently, with eleven board members to be appointed by the president subject to senate confirmation.<ref name="time072875"/>
LSC was created by the Legal Services Corporation Act of 1974 ({{USPL|93|355}}).<ref name="lsc-act">{{cite web | url=http://www.lsc.gov/laws/act.php | title=LSC Act and Other Statutes | publisher=Legal Services Corporation | date=1974-07-25 | accessdate=2008-02-02}}</ref> The LSC Act contains certain rules and restrictions regarding what LSC grantees can do.<ref name="lsc-act"/> The initial budget was set at $90 million.<ref name="brock-96"/>
Naming and confirmation of the first LSC board was delayed by inaction and opposition,<ref name="time072875"/> but by July 1975 President [[Gerald R. Ford]] had named, and the Senate approved, the first board, with [[Cornell University Law School]] Dean [[Roger Conant Cramton]] as its first chair.<ref name="time072875"/> Debate existed from the start among the board members as to whether LSC's role should be the OEO's one of using lawsuits and other means to attack broad underlying difficulties of the poor, or whether the focus should be more narrowly defined to addressing small, specific situations.<ref name="brock-96"/><ref name="time072875"/> The LSC Act said that the organization was to pursue "equal access to justice," but Cramton wrote that while the law was intended to proscribe the blatantly political objects of the 1960s OEO work, it was worded ambiguously.<ref name="brock-96"/>
===Carter era=== In December 1977, President [[Jimmy Carter]] nominated [[Hillary Rodham]] to the board of directors of the LSC,<ref name="carter-nom"/> for a term to expire in July 1980.<ref name="carter-nom">{{cite web | url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=7026 | title=Jimmy Carter: Nominations Submitted to the Senate, Week Ending Friday, December 16th, 1977 | work=American Presidency Project | accessdate=2007-09-03}}</ref> Rodham, an attorney with [[Rose Law Firm]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]] and the wife of [[Arkansas Attorney General]] [[Bill Clinton]], had a background in children's law and policy and had worked in providing legal services for the poor while at [[Yale Law School]]. She had also done 1976 campaign coordination work for Carter in [[Indiana]].<ref name="lh">[[Hillary Rodham Clinton]], ''[[Living History (book)|Living History]]'', [[Simon & Schuster]], 2003, {{ISBN|0-7432-2224-5}}, pp. 77–78.</ref><ref name="bernstein-book"/> This was a [[recess appointment]], so Rodham took her place on the board without immediate Senate confirmation. Rodham was nominated again in January 1978 as a regular appointment.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=29817 | title=Jimmy Carter: Nominations Submitted to the Senate, Week Ending Friday, January 27th, 1978 | work=American Presidency Project | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> In mid-1978, the Carter administration chose the thirty-year-old Rodham to become chair of the board, the first woman to become so.<ref name="brock-96"/> The position entailed her traveling monthly from Arkansas to [[Washington, D.C.]] for two-day meetings.<ref name="brock-96"/>
During Rodham's Senate confirmation hearings, she subscribed to the philosophy that LSC should seek to reform laws and regulations that it viewed as "unresponsive to the needs of the poor."<ref>Brock, ''Seduction of Hillary Rodham'', p. 98.</ref> Rodham was successful in getting increases in Congressional funding for LSC, stressing its usual role in providing low-income people with attorneys to assist them in commonplace legal issues and framed its funding as being neither a liberal nor a conservative cause.<ref>Brock, ''Seduction of Hillary Rodham'', p. 99–100.</ref> By her third year on the LSC board, Rodham had gotten the LSC budget tripled.<ref name="brock-105">Brock, ''Seduction of Hillary Rodham'', pp. 104–105.</ref> Opposition to LSC during this time came from both Republican Congressman [[James Sensenbrenner]], who favored a "[[judicare]]" approach of compensating private lawyers for work done for the poor,<ref name="brock-105"/> and [[The Conservative Caucus|Conservative Caucus]] head [[Howard Phillips (politician)|Howard Phillips]], who objected to LSC representing [[gay]]s.<ref name="brock-105"/>
LSC funding was at its highest-ever mark, in inflation adjusted dollars, in fiscal 1980,<ref name="bernstein-book">[[Carl Bernstein]], ''A Woman in Charge: The Life of Hillary Rodham Clinton'', [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]], {{ISBN|0-375-40766-9}}. pp. 132–133.</ref><ref name="ejm30">{{cite news | url=http://www.ejm.lsc.gov/ejmissue7/longclimbtojustice.htm | title=Long Climb to Justice | work=Equal Justice Magazine | publisher=Legal Services Corporation | date=Fall 2004 | accessdate=2008-03-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080405181359/http://www.ejm.lsc.gov/ejmissue7/longclimbtojustice.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-05}}</ref> with a budget of $303 million.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924030,00.html | title=Hybrid Help | publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' | date=1980-04-21 | accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> Some 6,200 poverty lawyers filed suits using its funds on behalf of 1.5 million eligible poor clients;<ref name="time112381">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,922707,00.html | title=One More Narrow Escape | author=Bennett H. Beach | publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' | date=1981-11-23 | accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref> the lawyers won almost 80 percent of their cases, which mostly involved divorces, evictions, repossessions, and interrupted payments from federal agencies.<ref name="time112381"/> For fiscal 1981 it was budgeted at $321 million.<ref name="time100383"/>
In June 1980, Carter renominated Rodham for another term on the board, to expire in July 1983.<ref name="carter-renom">{{cite web | url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=44676 | title=Jimmy Carter: Nominations Submitted to the Senate, Week Ending June 27th, 1980 | work=American Presidency Project | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> Sometime between about April 1980<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KWRBPOdZCdAC&q=%22legal+services+corporation%22+rodham+baby&dq=%22legal+services+corporation%22+rodham+baby&ei=Q0bVR928E47ijgG96oCFBA&pgis=1 | title=House Committee on Appropriations, Subcommittee on Departments of State, Justice, Commerce, the Judiciary, and Related Agencies Appropriations | year=1980 | publisher=[[U.S. House of Representatives]]}} Rodham is still chair after having given birth "a few weeks ago"; [[Chelsea Clinton]] was born on February 27, 1980.</ref> and September 1980,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://lawlibrary.rutgers.edu/cgi-bin/lib/hearing.cgi?file=81601609%20page=0001 | work=Background release, Legal Services Corporation, September 1980 | title=Hearings Before the Subcommittee on Courts, Civil Liberties, and the Administration of Justice, of the Committee of the Judiciary, House of Representatives | publisher=[[U.S. House of Representatives]] | date=September 21–27, 1979}} pp. 388–403, exact reference p. 398 shows McCalpin as chair in September 1980.</ref> [[F. William McCalpin]] replaced her as chair of the board. He would remain chair through late 1981.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE0DD133CF932A05751C1A966958260 | title= Still No End to Turmoil at Legal Services | author=Neil A. Lewis | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1990-12-31 | accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lrf.com/lewisrice/attorneys/Attorney_Resume.asp?key=FMCCALPIN | title=FMCCALPIN | publisher=Lewis Rice Attys. | accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref><ref name="wapo123182"/>
===Reagan era=== LSC was strongly opposed by some political groups. As [[Governor of California]] in the 1960s, [[Ronald Reagan]] had advocated elimination of all federal subsidies for free legal services to the poor in civil cases,<ref name="time112381"/> and had tried to block a grant to [[California Rural Legal Assistance]] in 1970.<ref name="time112381"/> Indeed, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine would state, "Of all the social programs growing out of the Great Society, there is none that Ronald Reagan dislikes more than the Legal Services Corporation."<ref name="time100383">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,926255,00.html | title=An Organization at War with Itself | publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' | date=1983-10-03 | accessdate=2008-02-03 | first1=David S. | last1=Jackson | first2=Michael S. | last2=Serrill}}</ref> CRLA's executive director would characterize Reagan's attitude towards the organization as akin to that of [[Darth Vader]].<ref name="time100383"/>
When President Reagan took office in January 1981, he attempted to eliminate the LSC by zero funding it.<ref name="time112381"/> Supporters of LSC rallied to defend it; [[American Bar Association]] president [[W. Reece Smith, Jr.]] led 200 lawyers to Washington to press its case.<ref name="ejm30"/> The [[U.S. House Judiciary Committee]] blocked Reagan's zero-funding action in May 1981,<ref name="nyt051481">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F30C15F73C5C0C778DDDAC0894D9484D81 | title=House Panel Rebuffs Reagan and Backs Keeping Legal Aid For Poor | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1981-05-14 | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> but did cut financing to $260 million for both of the next two years as well as place additional restrictions on LSC lawyers.<ref name="nyt051481"/> By the following month, the now Republican-controlled [[U.S. Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee]] had cut proposed financing to $100 million,<ref name="nyt061681">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F30714F6385C0C758DDDAF0894D9484D81 | title=House Action Near in Fight Over Legal Aid | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1981-06-18 | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> as part of what ''[[The New York Times]]'' deemed an "increasingly bitter ideological struggle".<ref name="nyt061681"/> Moreover, Reagan administration officials accused LSC of having "concealed and understated" its lobbying activity and support for politically motivated legislation.<ref name="nyt061681"/>
In November 1981, the Reagan administration, although still hoping to eliminate LSC, decided to replace all eleven LSC board members with nominations of their own.<ref name="nyt110881">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F50E10FA355D0C7B8CDDA80994D9484D81 | title=Coast Lawyer Reported As Legal Aid Choice | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1981-11-08 | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> For the new chairman they chose Ronald Zumbrun, president of the ideologically opposite [[Pacific Legal Foundation]],<ref name="nyt110881"/> which had previously defended the state of California against several legal aid lawsuits.<ref name="nyt110881"/> For fiscal 1982, LSC's budget was reduced by 25 percent to $241 million,<ref name="time112381"/> with new rules prohibiting most class action suits and lobbying.<ref name="time112381"/> Zumbrun's nomination was sufficiently controversial that in January 1982, the Reagan administration dropped it, and instead made a [[recess appointment]] of William J. Olson to be chair.<ref name="nyt010182">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F70E14F9385C0C728CDDA80894DA484D81 | title=Reagan Chooses Lawyer as Chief of Legal Aid Agency for the Poor | author=Irvin Molotsky | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1982-01-01 | accessdate=2008-02-19}}</ref> Olson had headed the Reagan transition team dealing with LSC and had personally recommended its abolition, so LSC advocates were not mollified.<ref name="nyt010182"/>
At the same time, the Reagan administration had named six other board members as recess appointments.<ref name="nyt010182"/> In February 1982, the Carter-appointed members of the previously existing board filed suit to against the recess appointments, claiming they were unlawful and that they should be enjoined from holding meetings.<ref name="brock-110">Brock, ''Seduction of Hillary Rodham'', pp. 110–111.</ref> Rodham hired fellow [[Rose Law Firm]] associate [[Vince Foster]] to represent her in the case<ref name="brock-110"/> and to seek a restraining order against Reagan.<ref name="bernstein-book"/> The Reagan nominees may <!-- not sure Bernstein is right on this --> have been prohibited from meeting with the Legal Service Corporation before confirmation.<ref name="bernstein-book"/>
Rodham also prodded Senate Democrats to vote against Reagan's nominees.<ref name="bernstein-book"/> The nominees did undergo heavy criticism in Congress, with one labeled a bigot and Olson lambasted for his transition position.<ref name="brock-110"/> In March 1982, yet another new chair was named, [[Indiana University]] law professor [[William F. Harvey]],<ref>{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEFDC153BF935A35750C0A964948260 | title= Legal Services Chief Picked | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher=United Press International | date=1982-03-06 | accessdate=2008-01-23}}</ref> although Olson would remain on the board.<ref name="nyt120982"/> Harvey and Rodham had a conference call in which Rodham reiterated her desire for the lawsuit.<ref name="brock-110"/> That action, ''McCalpin v. Dana'',<ref name="mvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.altlaw.org/v1/cases/420676 |title=McCALPIN v. DURANT |publisher=[[United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit]] |date=1985-06-25 |accessdate=2008-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090804134421/http://www.altlaw.org/v1/cases/420676 |archivedate=August 4, 2009 }}</ref> was decided in favor of the defendants by [[summary judgment]] in October 1982.<ref name="mvd"/>
By December 1982, the Senate was willing to confirm six of Reagan's more moderate nominees, but not Harvey, Olson, and another;<ref name="nyt121982"/> the Reagan administration instead pulled the names of all of them.<ref name="nyt120982">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F70B12F9355D0C7A8CDDAB0994DA484D81 | title=Reagan Withdraws 9 Nominees to Legal Unit | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1982-12-09 | accessdate=2008-03-08}}</ref> This board then closed its last meeting in a public debacle,<ref name="nyt121982">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F20F1EF63D5C0C7A8DDDAB0994DA484D81 | title=Politics and Perks Revive Reagan Fight on Legal Aid | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1982-12-19 | accessdate=2008-03-08}}</ref> with Olson lambasting LSC as full of "abuses and rampant illegality" and a "waste of the taxpayers' money through the funding of the left,"<ref name="nyt121982"/> while being harangued by a hostile audience.<ref name="nyt121982"/> And too, the Reagan appointees to the board were being criticized for collecting substantially higher fees than previous board members.<ref name="wapo123182">{{cite news | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost_historical/access/125172272.html | title=July Memo Warned Legal Services Officials on Fees | author=Mary Thornton | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | date=1982-12-31 | accessdate=2008-03-08 | format=Fee required}}</ref><ref name="nyt121982"/>
In September 1983 the [[General Accounting Office]] found that in early 1981, LSC officials and its local affiliates had used federal funds in assembling opposition to Reagan's efforts to eliminate LSC, and that this use had been in violation of the LSC Act's restrictions against such political activity.<ref name="nyt092183">{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F50F12F73A5C0C728EDDA00894DB484D81 | title=Ex-Legal Aid Officials Accused of Fund Abuse | author=Stuart Taylor Jr. | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=1983-09-21 | accessdate=2008-02-18}}</ref> Such actions against the LSC Act were not crimes, and the GAO report did not claim any crimes had taken place.<ref name="nyt092183"/> The investigation had been initiated by the LSC of 1983 ordering a series of "raids" on their own offices to attempt to discover evidence of LSC of 1981 actions questionable,<ref name="time100383"/> prompting ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine to declare LSC "an organization at war with itself."<ref name="time100383"/>
More recess appointments were made by Reagan in late 1983, in 1984, and in early 1985, with again none of them being confirmed by the Senate.<ref name="mvd"/> Indeed, LSC's board would go a total of three and a half years populated by recess appointments.<ref name="mvd"/> Finally in June 1985 the Senate confirmed the latest batch of Reagan nominations.<ref name="mvd"/> The Carter board lawsuit, since renamed and appealed as ''McCalpin v. Durant'' to the [[United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit]], was then decided later in June 1985 as moot.<ref name="mvd"/>
===George H. W. Bush era=== Overt White House hostility towards LSC ended with the [[George H. W. Bush administration]], with calls for level funding rather than decreases.<ref name="ejm30"/> Under board chair George Wittgraff, LSC began to ease relations with private lawyers and with state grantees.<ref name="ejm30"/> In fiscal 1992, LSC saw a funding increase back to $350 million.<ref name="ejm30"/>
===Clinton era=== The first two years of the [[Clinton administration]] saw more growth for LSC, as former chair McCalpin returned to the board and the previous former chair was now [[First Lady of the United States]] [[Hillary Rodham Clinton]].<ref name="ejm30"/> Funding rose to a high mark in absolute terms of $400 million for fiscal years 1994 and 1995.<ref name="ejm30"/>
Things turned upon the advent of the [[Republican Revolution]].<ref name="ejm30"/> In fiscal 1996, once the Republican party had taken over Congress the year prior, LSC had its funding cut again, from $400 million to $278 million.<ref name="wapo060196">{{cite news | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-785874.html | title=Attacked as Left-Leaning, Legal Services Suffers Deep Cuts | author=William Booth | publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' | date=1996-06-01 | accessdate=2008-02-07 | format=fee required}}</ref> A new set of much more extensive restrictions were added to LSC grantees. The organization's supporters expressed disappointment that the Clinton administration did not make LSC a critical priority in its budget battles with the Republican Congress, especially given Hillary Clinton's former role in it.<ref name="wapo060196"/>
As part of a comprehensive "[[welfare reform]]" of federal welfare laws beginning in 1996, most significantly the [[Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act]], Congress imposed restrictions on the types of work that LSC grantee legal services organizations could engage in. For example, LSC-funded organizations could no longer serve as counsel in class action lawsuits<ref name="wapo060196"/> challenging the way public benefits are administered. Additionally, LSC grantees faced tightened restrictions on representing immigrants, specifically those illegally in the country.<ref name="wapo060196"/> However, in 2001, the restriction on welfare advocacy was ruled unconstitutional in ''[[Legal Services Corp. v. Velazquez]]''.
However, non-LSC funded organizations are not subject to these restrictions leading the legal services community to adopt a two-track approach: LSC restricted counsel taking on individual clients but not engaging in class actions, and non-restricted counsel (using private donor funding) both taking on individuals as well as engaging in otherwise restricted litigation. Poverty lawyers in both tracks still work together where they can, being careful not to run afoul of LSC restrictions.
===George W. Bush era=== According to LSC's 2009 report "Documenting the Justice Gap in America: The Current Unmet Civil Legal Needs of Low-Income Americans," all legal aid offices nationwide, LSC-funded or not, were together able to meet only about 20 percent of the estimated legal needs of low-income people in the [[United States]].<ref>[http://www.lsc.gov/press/documents/LSC%20Justice%20Gap_FINAL_1001.pdf ''Documenting the Justice Gap in America: The Current Unmet Civil Legal Needs of Low-Income Americans''], pages 4 and 9. Legal Services Corporation, September 2005.</ref>
For 2007, LSC had a budget of some $350 million.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lsc.gov/about/FY07app.php | title=FY 2007 Appropriation | publisher=Legal Services Corporation | accessdate=2008-02-03}}</ref>
===Obama era=== [[File:FEMA - 45644 - Mass Care Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) signing at FEMA Headquarters.jpg|thumb|John Eidleman, Senior Program Counsel of Legal Services Corporation, standing next to [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] Administrator W. Craig Fugate and [[American Red Cross]] President and CEO [[Gail J. McGovern]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] on October 22, 2010.]]
In 2009 during the [[Obama administration]], the LSC was on the path to getting a $50 million increase in its $390 million budget.<ref name="cbs072809">{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/07/28/eveningnews/main5194529.shtml | title=Legal Services Investigated for Waste | author=Sharyl Attkisson | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=July 28, 2009}}</ref>
However, the LSC came under criticism from Senator [[Charles Grassley]], who said, "There's just a lot of money being wasted," citing several [[General Accounting Office]] and [[Inspector General]] reports.<ref name="cbs072809"/>
By fiscal 2011, the annual budget amount for the LSC was $420 million.<ref name="lthskj">[http://legaltimes.typepad.com/blt/2011/02/obama-proposes-legal-services-corp-budget-increase.html Obama Proposes Legal Services Corp. Budget Increase – The BLT: The Blog of Legal Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In early 2011, House now-majority Republican proposed a $75 million reduction in that current-year amount, while Obama's suggestion budget proposed a $30 million increase for the subsequent year.<ref name="lthskj"/>
On December 16, 2014, the President signed into law the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act for FY 2015 that includes $375 million for LSC.<ref name="2013 budget"/>
===Trump era=== In February 2017, the Trump administration identified LSC as one of a number of programs that could be eliminated in its proposed budget.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lafraniere|first1=Sharon|last2=Rappeport|first2=Alan|title=Popular Domestic Programs Face Ax Under First Trump Budget|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/17/us/politics/trump-program-eliminations-white-house-budget-office.html|work=The New York Times|date=February 17, 2017}}</ref> However despite this intentioning, the [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018]] "Omnibus bill" that passed Congress and was signed by the executive in March 2018 actually contained a modest increase for the LSC.<ref>https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/03/23/heres-whats-in-the-budget-bill-nobodys-bothered-to-read-217701</ref>
==Restrictions== Due to the up-and-down nature of LSC's political history, there are many restrictions on lobbying, advocacy, and general impact work which apply to LSC-funded organizations. Here they are broken into categories of expressly forbidden, forbidden with LSC funds, and expressly permitted.
'''Recipients may never:''' * Publicly identify LSC or the recipient with any partisan or nonpartisan political activity or a candidate for office, or encourage others to do so (45 CFR 1608.4)<ref name="lsc.gov">[http://www.lsc.gov/about/regulations-rules/lsc-regulations-cfr-45-part-1600-et-seq LSC Regulations CFR 45 Part 1600 et. seq. | LSC - Legal Services Corporation: America's Partner for Equal Justice<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Staff attorneys may not use their position or authority to influence elections or coerce anyone to contribute to a political cause (45 CFR 1608.5)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Run for office (45 CFR 1608.5(c))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Register, transport to polls, or otherwise assist voters in election-related activities (45 CFR 1608.6)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Use non-LSC funds for anything prohibited by the LSC Act, unless it is specifically allowed in 45 CFR 1610.4, 1610.6, or 1610.7 (45 CFR 1610.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Lobby. In the language of the regulation, recipient organizations may not attempt to influence the passage or defeat of a bill, constitutional amendment, initiative, referendum, executive order, or provision which appropriates funds or defines the functions or authority of LSC or the recipient (45 CFR 1612.3).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* This includes using resources from a recipient organization to support lobbying efforts on employees' own time – don't even take an envelope! (45 CFR 1612.3(c))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* The caveat is that organizations may lobby at the State and local level with non-LSC funds regarding funding for their organization (45 CFR 1612.6(f)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Grassroots lobby (45 CFR 1612.4)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * During working hours or with resources provided by an LSC-funded organization, employees may not participate or encourage others to participate in public demonstrations, boycotts, picketing, or strikes. This must be on personal time (45 CFR 1612.7(a)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Employees of recipients may never engage in rioting or civil disturbances, actions which violate a court-imposed injunction, or take part in illegal activity of any kind (45 CFR 1612.7(b))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Support or conduct training sessions which advocate particular public policies, encourage or facilitate prohibited political activities, disseminate information about such policies or activities, or train participants to engage in prohibited activities (45 CFR 1612.8(a))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Form or organize an association, labor union, or other similar organization. This is distinct from holding informational meetings for attorneys or forming organizations of eligible clients for advice on service delivery (both of which are allowed). You may also advise your clients on the legal procedures for forming these types of organizations themselves, and even help them with documents like bylaws (45 CFR 1612.9).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Represent clients in criminal proceedings (unless you are appointed by a court or a situation arises out of your representation of the client in a civil case) (45 CFR 1613)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Initiate or participate in a class action suit (45 CFR 1617.3), although you may represent individuals who want to remove themselves from the suit or have not received the settlement ordered by the court (45 CFR 1617.2(b)(2)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Provide legal assistance to ineligible aliens (45 CFR 1626.3; see 45 CFR 1626.5 to judge eligibility), unless the alien in question is, or is the parent of someone subject to battery or extreme cruelty by a spouse, parent, or member of their spouse's or parent's family residing in the same household. In this case, non-LSC funds must be used for the case (45 CFR 1626.4).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Participate in any activity related to the redistricting of a legislative, judicial, or elective district at any level of government (45 CFR 1632.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Defend clients in eviction proceedings from a public housing unit if that client has been charged with or convicted of the sale, distribution, or manufacture of controlled substances, or of possession with the intent to sell or distribute (45 CFR 1633.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Participate in civil litigation on behalf of an incarcerated person, as plaintiff or defendant, nor any administrative hearing challenging the conditions of incarceration (45 CFR 1637.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Represent, nor refer for representation by another recipient any client gained through in-person, unsolicited advice (45 CFR 1638.3) * Participate in legislation, lobbying, or rulemaking involving efforts to reform Federal or State welfare systems (45 CFR 1639.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* [[Legal Services Corp. v. Velazquez|LSC v. Velasquez (2001)]] was considered a victory by those trying to chip away at LSC regulations. It didn't change the overall prohibition, but it deleted the restriction barring litigation which attempts to change welfare law in the context of representing an individual client (45 CFR 1693.4).<ref name="lsc.gov"/>
'''Recipients may, with non-LSC funding:'''
In many of their regulations, LSC only states activities that their funding cannot be used to support. In 45 CFR 1610.2(c)–(h), however, several different types of non-LSC funding are defined:
:“(c) IOLTA funds means funds derived from programs established by State court rules or :legislation that collect and distribute interest on lawyers' trust accounts. :(d) Non-LSC funds means funds derived from a source other than the Corporation. :(e) Private funds means funds derived from an individual or entity other than a :governmental source or LSC. :(f) Public funds means non-LSC funds derived from a Federal, State, or local government or :instrumentality of a government. For purposes of this part, IOLTA funds shall be treated in :the same manner as public funds... :(h) Tribal funds means funds received from an Indian tribe or from a private nonprofit :foundation or organization for the benefit of Indians or Indian tribes."<ref name="lsc.gov"/>
With these definitions in mind, 45 CFR 1610.4 goes on to specify what each type of funding can be used for: * Tribal funds can be used for whatever purpose they were granted (45 CFR 1610.4(a))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Public, IOLTA, and Private funds can be used for whatever purpose they were granted, as long as it doesn't violate LSC's regulations (45 CFR 1610.4(b)-(c))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Non-LSC funds generally can be used to assist clients who are not financially eligible under LSC guidelines (45 CFR 1610.4(d))<ref name="lsc.gov"/>
In addition, the category of general non-LSC funds may be used to: * Support a political party, association, candidate, ballot measure, initiative, or referendum – but not during working hours or at the recipient's office location (45 CFR 1608.3(b))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Respond to a written request from an agency, legislative body, elected official, etc. to participate in rulemaking or to provide oral or written testimony in order to provide information which may include analysis and/or comments on legislation (45 CFR 1612.6(a))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* However, you can only provide your testimony to the requesting party or parties – it cannot be distributed to a wider audience (45 CFR 1612.6(b));<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* You may not arrange for the written request (45 CFR 1612.6(c));<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* And, you must report this activity to LSC (45 CFR 1612.6(d)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Recipients may also provide oral or written comments to an agency in a public rulemaking session without having been requested (45 CFR 1612.6(e))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Lobby at the State or local level regarding the recipient's funding (45 CFR 1612.6(f))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Assist an ineligible alien or his or her child who has been subjected to battery and/ or extreme cruelty by the alien's parent, spouse, or a member of the parent's or spouse's family residing in the same household as the alien. To qualify, the alien him- or herself cannot have participated in the abuse, and the representation must be related to preventing or ending the abuse (45 CFR 1626.4(a)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Comment in a public rulemaking proceeding or respond to a written request for testimony in a legislative session or committee meeting concerning welfare reform (45 CFR 1639.5)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Participate in legal activity which seeks to obtain or compel an individual or institution to provide or assist with euthanasia or assisted suicide (45 CFR 1643.3) or a "nontherapeutic abortion" (term not defined) (LSC Act §1007(b)(8)<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.lsc.gov/about/lsc-act-other-laws/lsc-act LSC Act | LSC – Legal Services Corporation: America's Partner for Equal Justice<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> or the 1996 Appropriations Act §504(a)(14))<ref>http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-104hr3019eas/pdf/BILLS-104hr3019eas.pdf</ref> * Participate in legal activity seeking to desegregate elementary or secondary schools (LSC Act §1007(b)(9))<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * Participate in legal activity relating to violation(s) of the Military Selective Service Act or desertion from the Armed Forces of the United States (LSC Act §1007 (b)(10))<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
'''Recipients may, with any funding:''' * Accept fee-generating cases in situations in which local pro bono attorneys or the referral service are not viable options (45 CFR 1609.3)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* In terms of accounting, fees garnered from these services must go into the same category as the recipient's LSC grant in the same proportion that LSC funds supported the activity (versus other funds) (45 CFR 1609.4)<ref name="lsc.gov"/> :* This regulation was changed in Section 533 of the 2010 Appropriations Act from a statutory prohibition (which had been implemented in the 1996 Appropriations Act Section 504(a)) * Accept reimbursement from clients for out-of-pocket expenses related to their case, if the client has agreed to pay ahead of time and in writing (45 CFR 1609.5(a))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Represent eligible clients at the administrative level (45 CFR 1612.5(a))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Initiate or participate in litigation challenging a governmental agency's rules, regulations, policies, etc. (45 CFR 1612.5(b))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Communication with an agency to receive information (45 CFR 1612.5(c)(2))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Informing clients, other recipients, etc. about new or proposed statutes, executive orders, or administrative regulations. Note that legislation is not listed here (45 CFR 1612.5(c)(3)).<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Contact LSC to comment on its rules (45 CFR 1612.5(c)(4))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Advise a client of his or her right to contact an elected official (45 CFR 1612.5(c)(6))<ref name="lsc.gov"/> * Provide assistance to eligible aliens (45 CFR 1626.5; also lists criteria for eligibility), as well as specific categories of other aliens (45 CFR 1626.10 and 1626.11)<ref name="lsc.gov"/>
==Board of directors== LSC is headed by an 11-member Board of Directors appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate.<ref name="lsc-board"/> By law, the Board is bipartisan: no more than six members may be of the same political party.<ref name="lsc-board"/> The current composition of the board is: * Board Chair: [[John G. Levi]] * Vice Chair: [[Martha Minow]] * Members: [[Robert J. Grey, Jr.|Robert J. Grey Jr.]], Charles N.W. Keckler, Harry J.F. Korrell III, Victor B. Maddox, Laurie Mikva, Father Pius Pietrzyk, O.P., Julie A. Reiskin, and Gloria Valencia-Weber. Sharon L. Browne resigned from the board in December 2014.
The chairs of the LSC board throughout its history have included: * Roger Conant Cramton * [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary Rodham]] * [[F. William McCalpin]] * [[William F. Harvey]] * Robert Emmett McCarthy * [[Clark Durant|William C. Durant III]] * George W. Wittgraf * Douglas S. Eakeley * Frank B. Strickland
== Headquarters == By law, LSC's headquarters is located in Washington, D.C. In the 1970s and 1980s, LSC also had regional offices. LSC currently has one office in Washington D.C. that administers all of LSC's work. LSC itself does not provide legal representation to the poor.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{PoliticsES}} :''Go directly to the [[Constitutions of Spain#Table|Table]]'' Spain has [[Promulgation|proclaimed]] a number of Constitutions. The current [[Spanish Constitution of 1978|Magna Carta]] of 1978 is the culmination of the [[Spanish transition to democracy]]. The idea of a national constitution for Spain arose from the [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]] initiated as a result of the [[French Revolution]] The earliest document recognized as such was [[Spanish Constitution of 1812|La Pepa]] passed in 1812 as a result of the [[Peninsular War]] (1807–1814), which was a [[War|military conflict]] between the [[First French Empire]] and the allied powers of the [[Spanish Empire]], the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] and the [[Kingdom of Portugal]] for control of the [[Iberian Peninsula]] during the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. During the [[Francoist State]], there were many attempts to create stable institutions that did not (at least directly) emanate from Fransisco Franco as they did in the post-war period. The Fundamental Laws of the Realm (Spanish: ''Leyes Fundamentales del Reino'') were a constitution in parts enacted through nearly 20 years starting in the 1950s. They established the very institutions that would later, under [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] and Prime Minister [[Adolfo Suárez]], commit "constitutional suicide" and pass the Political Reform Act, starting the [[Spanish transition to democracy]]. Most of those Laws theoretically provided for a quite free state, but ultimately the power of the [[Caudillo]] was supreme. Finally, the constitution in force is similar to the (unwritten) British democratic monarchy model, but the [[Catalan self-determination referendum, 2014]] has provoked calls for an entirely democratic federal republican model. Below there is a comprehensive [[Constitutions of Spain#Table|table]], but this is an overview: * 1808–1814 Napoleonic restructuring from royal edict to bicameral parliament * 1812 La Pepa The first attempt at decentralization or republicanism * 1814 La Pepa derogated by the [[Monarchy of Spain|King]] * 1834 Absolute monarchy * 1837 Constitutional monarchy * 1845 Regency empowerment * 1856 Failed attempt at democracy * 1869 Another failed attempt at democracy * 1873 [[First Spanish Republic|1st Democratic Republic]] * 1876 Failed attempt to become a federal republic * 1931 [[Second Spanish Republic|2nd Democratic Republic]] * 1936 Martial law under [[Francisco Franco]] * 1939 – 1978 [[Francoist Spain]] * 1978 Transition to [[History of Spain (1975–present)|democratic monarchy]] ==Table== {|class="wikitable" !style="width:10%"|Name !style="width:10%"|In force !style="width:5%"|Form of government !style="width:15%"|Democracy !style="width:18%"|Repealed !style="width:40%"|Observations |- |align="center"|[[Bayonne Statute]]
[[Royal Charter]] |align="center"|1808–1814 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Bicameral parliament with semi-elective lower house. |align="center"|[[Peninsular War]] lost by [[Joseph Bonaparte|Joseph I]]. |align="center"|Not recognized by the Spanish patriots during the war. Most of its contents were to be enacted through the 1810s, so it did not actually work. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1812|Constitution of 1812]] |align="center"|1812–1814
1820–1823
1836–1837 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Elected parliament. |align="center"|[[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Ferdinand VII]] reinstated [[Absolutism (European history)|absolutism]] in 1814 and again in 1823. Superseded in 1837. |align="center"|The Crown was granted wide-ranging veto powers, which Ferdinand VII used to prevent the liberal governments from functioning. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Royal Statute of 1834|Royal Statute of 1834]]
Royal Charter |align="center"|1834–1836 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Bicameral parliament with elected lower house and appointed Senate. |align="center"|Regent forced to reinstate the 1812 Constitution after a military ''[[pronunciamiento]]''. |align="center"|Granted by [[Maria Christina of Austria|Maria Christina]] in order to get support from the liberals in the [[First Carlist War]]. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1837|Constitution of 1837]] |align="center"|1837–1845 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"| |align="center"|Superseded. |align="center"|Partially suspended by [[Baldomero Espartero]] to rule by decree between 1840 and 1843. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1845|Constitution of 1845]] |align="center"|1845–1869 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Parliament elected by [[censitary suffrage]]. |align="center"|[[Isabella II of Spain|Isabella II]] and her Government overthrown in the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|Glorious Revolution of 1868]]. |align="center"|[[Doctrinaires|Doctrinaire]] attempt to exploit the plots against the young Isabella and the Regency in order to reinforce the monarchy |- |align="center"|[[Draft Spanish Constitution of 1856|Constitution of 1856]] |align="center"|''Not enacted'' |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Parliament elected by censitary suffrage. |align="center"|Scrapped by the new government. |align="center"|Passed by the Parliament but not enacted by Isabella II as moderate liberals returned to power. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1869|Constitution of 1869]] |align="center"|1869–1876 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Parliament elected by universal male suffrage. |align="center"|Republic declared by the Cortes after the abdication of [[Amadeo I of Spain|Amadeo I]]. |align="center"|An interim compromise between royalist conservatives and republican progressives |- |align="center"|[[Draft Spanish Constitution of 1873|Constitution of 1873]] |align="center"|''Not enacted'' |align="center"|Federal republic |align="center"|Unicameral parliament elected by universal male suffrage. |align="center"|[[Arsenio Martínez Campos]] led a successful ''pronunciamiento'' restoring the [[Spain under the Restoration|Bourbon monarchy]]. |align="center"|Republic collapsed before even passing the Constitution, mainly due to wide disagreement over the federalism ''vs'' centralism issue. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1876|Constitution of 1876]] |align="center"|1876–1931 |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Parliament elected, firstly by censitary, then universal male suffrage from the 1890s. |align="center"|[[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] instated after [[Alfonso XIII of Spain|Alphonse XIII]] fled Spain. |While theoretically democratic, elections were routinely rigged by the governing party, and in practice power was shared by two alternating parties (the [[turno]] system). During [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera's]] dictatorship (1923–1930) many of its articles were suspended in a de facto dictatorship. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1931|Constitution of 1931]] |align="center"|1931–1939 |align="center"|Parliamentary republic |align="center"|Unicameral parliament, firstly with universal male suffrage, then [[female suffrage]] from 1933. |align="center"|[[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] lost by the Republican side. |align="center"|During the Civil War (1936–1939) it was abolished by the Nationalists and widely disregarded in the Republican zone. |- |align="center"|[[Fundamental Laws of the Realm]] |align="center"|1938–1978 |align="center"|Military dictatorship |align="center"|Partially elected unicameral parliament with little powers of its own. |align="center"|Superseded when Parliament adopted the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978|Constitution of 1978]]. |align="center"|A set of laws enacted by the caudillo [[Francisco Franco]] in order to shape his political regime and adapt it to changes. The individual laws passed under Franco are: ''Fuero del Trabajo'' (1938), ''Ley Constitutiva de las Cortes'' (1942), ''Fuero de los Españoles'' (1945), ''Ley del Referéndum Nacional'' (1945), ''Ley de Sucesión en la Jefatura del Estado'' (1945), ''Ley de Principios del Movimiento Nacional'' (1958), and ''Ley Orgánica del Estado'' (1967). The Law for Political Reform ''(Ley de Reforma Política)'' of 1977, last of the Fundamental Laws and passed after Franco's death, started the [[Spanish transition to democracy]]. |- |align="center"|[[Spanish Constitution of 1978|Constitution of 1978]] |align="center"|1978–present |align="center"|Constitutional monarchy |align="center"|Parliamentary democracy with bicameral, elective parliament. |align="center"|Currently in force. |align="center"|First in Spanish constitutional history not to grant any emergency power (i.e. sacking the PM, dissolving the Cortes) to the Head of State. |} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071012233918/http://www.constitucion.es/otras_constituciones/espana/index.html Text of all Spanish Constitutions, except the 1808 one] {{-}} {{Constitutions of Spain}} {{Constitution of Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Constitutions Of Spain}} [[Category:Constitutions of Spain]] [[Category:Constitutional history|Spain]]

[[File:Louise and Steven Weinberg with Queen Beatrix 1983.jpg|thumb|270px|Louise and [[Steven Weinberg]] with [[Queen Beatrix]] in 1983]] '''Louise Weinberg''' is an American legal scholar, writing in the fields of federal courts, constitutional law, the conflict of laws, and Supreme Court history. A professor of law at the [[University of Texas School of Law]] in Austin, Weinberg holds the endowed William B. Bates Chair in the Administration of Justice,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://law.utexas.edu/faculty/louise-weinberg/|title=Faculty web page, Louise Weinberg, the University of Texas School of Law.}}</ref> the chair previously held by Charles Alan Wright, and has revived Charles Alan Wright’s famous Supreme Court Seminar.
Weinberg is a legal theorist in the tradition of the American legal realists. She is particularly known for *her writings on “federal common law”<ref>{{Cite web|title=Edward Purcell, BRANDEIS AND THE PROGRESSIVE CONSTITUTION, Chapter IV.}}</ref> *the concept, “judicial federalism”<ref>{{Cite web|title=Stuart, CONCEPTS OF FEDERALISM (1979).}}</ref> *her proposed reorganization of theory in the conflict of laws<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.illinoislawreview.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Weinberg.pdf|title=Weinberg, A Radically Transformed Restatement for Conflicts (University of Illinois Law Review (2015).}}</ref> *her 70-page defense, against latter-day attacks, of ''Marbury v. Madison'' as “our greatest case.”<ref>{{Cite web|title=[Justice] Stephen Breyer, MAKING OUR DEMOCRACY WORK (2011); Sullivan & Gunther, CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (15th ed.).}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://law.utexas.edu/faculty/publications/2003-Our-Marbury/download|title=Weinberg, Our Marbury (Virginia Law Review 2003).}}</ref>
== Academic Career == Prior to coming to the University of Texas, Weinberg was a teaching fellow at Harvard Law School, taught an undergraduate law course at Brandeis University, was tenured at Suffolk Law School, and was a visiting professor at Stanford Law School.
At Texas, Weinberg has been honored with various named professorships and is now holder of the endowed William B. Bates Chair in the Administration of Justice, formerly held by Charles Alan Wright. She teaches Federal Courts and Constitutional Law, and has revived the famous Supreme Court Seminar originated at Texas by Wright.
== Education and Clerkship == Weinberg was graduated summa cum laude from Cornell University. She has two Harvard law degrees, the J.D. and the LL.M. She clerked for the eminent jurist, [[Charles Edward Wyzanski Jr.]]
==Practice of Law == Before embarking on her academic career, Weinberg was Associate in Litigation with Bingham, Dana and Gould, [[Boston]], later Bingham, McCutcheon.
== Memberships == Weinberg is an elected member of the [[American Law Institute]] , the legal profession's learned academy,<ref>{{Cite web|title=See current Directory of Members, American Law Institute, Philadelphia.}}</ref> where she is currently an invited Adviser to its project for Restatement (Third) of Conflict of Laws.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ali.org/projects/show/conflict-laws/#_participants|title=American Law Institute, Project, Conflict of Laws, Advisers.}}</ref>
At the [[Association of American Law Schools]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=See current AALS Directory of Law Teachers..}}</ref> the legal academics' learned society, she has been * elected on three separate occasions to serve as Chair of its Section on Federal Courts
* elected on two separate occasions to serve as Chair of its Section on Conflict of Laws
* elected Chair of its Section on Admiralty.
Weinberg is an elected member of the [[Philosophical Society of Texas]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pstx.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=140:members-of-..|title=Directory of Members, The Philosophical Society of Texas.}}</ref>
A member of Phi Beta Kappa, Weinberg serves on its Board of Directors in Austin.
Weinberg has also served as a Forum Fellow at the [[World Economic Forum ]] at Davos, Switzerland.
== Books == *''Federal Courts: Judicial Federalism and Judicial Power'' (West Pub. Co., 1200 pp. 1994) & Supps. *''Conflict of Laws'' (Matthew Bender 2011, 2002, 1996) (co-authors William Richman and William Reynolds).
== Recent Scholarly Papers == *Luther v. Borden: A Taney-Court Mystery Solved (''Pace Law Review'' 2017) *A Radically Transformed Restatement for Conflicts ''(University of Illinois Law Review'' 2015) *What We Don’t Talk About When We Talk About Extraterritoriality: Kiobel and the Conflict of Laws (''Cornell Law Review'' 2014) *A General Theory of Governance: Due Process and Lawmaking Power (''William & Mary Law Review'' (2013) *Unlikely Beginnings of Modern Constitutional Thought (''University of Pennsylvania Journal of Constitutional Law'' 2012) *The McReynolds Mystery Solved (''Denver University Law Review'' 2011)
== Earlier Notable Papers == *Courts, United States Federal (''The Oxford International Encyclopedia of Legal History'' 2009) *Overcoming Dred (''Constitutional Commentary'' 2007) *Dred Scott and the Crisis of 1860 (''Chicago-Kent Law Review'' 2007) *Theory Wars in the Conflict of Laws (''Michigan Law Review'' 2005) *Our Marbury (''Virginia Law Review'' 2003) *Of Theory and Theodicy: The Problem of Immoral Law ''(Law and Justice in a Multistate World'' 2002) *When Courts Decide Elections: The Constitutionality of Bush v. Gore (''Boston University Law Review'' 2002) *Of Sovereignty and Union: The Legends of Alden (''Notre Dame Law Review'' 2001) *Holmes' Failure (''Michigan Law Review'' 1997) *Fear and Federalism (Symposium, ''Ohio Northern University Law Review'' 1997) *Methodological Interventions and the Slavery Cases, or, Night-Thoughts of a Legal Realist (''Maryland Law Review'' 1997) *Political Questions and the Guarantee Clause (''University of Colorado Law Review'' 1994) *The Federal-State Conflict of Laws: “Actual” Conflicts (''Texas Law Review'' 1992) *Against Comity (''Georgetown Law Journal'' 1991) *The Monroe Mystery Solved: Beyond the “Unhappy History” Theory of Civil Rights Litigation (''Brigham Young University Law Review'' 1991) *Federal Common Law (''Northwestern University Law Review'' 1989) *On Departing from Forum Law (''Mercer Law Review'' 1984 (Anthologized in ''A Conflict-Of-Laws Anthology'' 1997)) *Choice of Law and Minimal Scrutiny (''University of Chicago Law Review'' 1982) (Anthologized in ''A Conflict-Of-Laws Anthology'' 1997)) *The New Judicial Federalism (''Stanford Law Review'' 1977).

Shreve, A Conflict-of-Laws Anthology (1997) (work anthologized) *Stuart, Concepts of Federalism (1979) *Westlaw.com (820 citations) *Social Science Research Network, 1,966 downloads) *United States Court of Appeals (4th Cir. 2016) *United States Court of Appeals (D.C. Cir. 2010) *Supreme Court of New Jersey (2008) *United States District Court (2000) *Court of Appeals of Arizona (1997)
== Personal Information and Early Life == Louise Weinberg was born in New York and raised in Forest Hills. She is married to [[Steven Weinberg]], the physicist and Nobel laureate. They have a married daughter and grandchild.
At the age of 14, Weinberg won first prize in ''Seventeen Magazine''’s national short story contest. She was the front-page columnist for her high school newspaper, and at Cornell she was drama critic for the ''Cornell Daily Sun''.
Louise and Steven Weinberg, with five other couples, founded The Tuesday Club of Austin, Texas, now with over 200 members and a branch in Atlanta. Co-founders included Hon. Jerre Williams and Hon. Mary Pearl Williams, Admiral [[Bobby Ray Inman]] and Nancy Inman, Austin-American Statesman Editor Arthur Rosenfeld and Ruth Rosenfeld, and Chancellor [[Hans Mark]] and Marion Mark.
Louise Weinberg is a member of Town and Gown, an Austin institution.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Current Membership Directory, Town and Gown, Headliners Club and Foundation, Austin TX.}}</ref>
As an early member of the Board of Directors of Ballet Austin, Louise Weinberg first proposed the establishment of the ballet school, now a flourishing arm of Ballet Austin.
Weinberg served on the Board of the Austin Foreign Affairs Council under the directorship of [[Philip Bobbitt]].

'''''Miller v. National Broadcasting Co.''''' {{law report|232|Cal. Rptr|668}} (1986) is a [[US tort law]] case on [[negligent infliction of emotional distress]]. ==Background== On October 30, 1979 an [[NBC]] camera crew was following a group of [[Los Angeles Fire Department]] firefighters and [[paramedics]]. A call came in about a man having a [[heart attack]]. The camera crew and the paramedics rushed to the home of Brownie and Dave Miller. The camera crew, without consent from anyone, rushed into the house with the paramedics and taped footage of Mr. Dave Miller having what would be a fatal heart attack. The crew later that night would put the footage on the air, also without consent. Brownie Miller filed suit against NBC, Ruben Norte (a producer for NBC) and the city of [[Los Angeles]] for trespass, invasion of privacy and infliction of emotional distress. ==Legal Issue== Does the media, even though they obtain consent from the group they are following (Police, firefighters, paramedics, etc.) have the same access privileges as the police of paramedics do if they are following them on scene? ==Decision== The Court ruled, ultimately, in favor of the plaintiff on the charges of Invasion of Privacy and infliction of Emotional Distress. ===Reasoning===
One seeking emergency medical attention does not thereby "open the door" for persons without any clearly identifiable and justifiable official reason who may wish to enter the premises where the medical aid is being administered…the clear line of demarcation between the public interest served by public officials and that served by private business must not be obscured.
==Disposition== Reversed- The [[California Courts of Appeal]] reversed the summary judgment of the District Court in favor of the defendants and ruled in favor of Brownie Miller. {{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=National Broadcasting Co. v. United States |ArgueDateA=February 10 |ArgueDateB=11 |ArgueYear=1943 |DecideDate=May 10 |DecideYear=1943 |FullName=National Broadcasting Company, Incorporated, ''et al.'' v. United States, ''et al.'' |USVol=319 |USPage=190 |ParallelCitations=63 S. Ct. 997; 87 [[L. Ed.]] 1344; 1943 [[U.S. LEXIS]] 1119; 1 Media L. Rep. 1965 |Prior=Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of New York |Subsequent= |Holding=The Federal Communications Commission can issue regulations pertaining to associations between broadcast networks and affiliated stations. |SCOTUS=1943-1945 |Majority=Frankfurter |JoinMajority=Stone, Reed, Douglas, Jackson |Dissent=Murphy |JoinDissent=Roberts |NotParticipating=Black and Rutledge |LawsApplied= }} '''''National Broadcasting Co. v. United States''''', 319 U.S. 190 (1943),{{ref|citation}} was a case in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] held on May 10, 1943 that the [[Federal Communications Commission]] had the power to issue regulations pertaining to associations between broadcasting networks and their affiliated stations, otherwise known as "chain networks." The case is important in the development of [[American administrative law]]. ==Legal principles== The scope of authority held by an agency is determined by the agency's [[organic statute (USA)|organic statute]]. Where Congress grants an agency the power to maintain and regulate an area guided by the "public interest, convenience, or necessity," such a grant of power can include the regulation of areas not explicitly contemplated by the organic statute, as long as they are within the scope of the purpose of the original statute. Note: The approach in this case takes a much more expansive approach than the earlier case of ''[[ICC v. Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway Co.]]'' which provided for more limited powers for administrative agencies. Specifically, ''ICC'' held that regulative powers must be expressly granted by statute and not implied, while ''NBC'' held that the issuance of regulations, though not expressly granted, are an acceptable way for the agency to fulfill its statutory obligations to serve the "public interest, convenience, or necessity." ==Facts and procedural posture== The FCC established [[Federal Communications Commission#Report on Chain Broadcasting|Chain Broadcasting Regulations]] in 1941, which specifically governed the licensing and content of chain broadcasting stations. [[NBC]] sued to enjoin the enforcement of the regulations. The [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] dismissed the complaint, ruling for the government, and NBC appealed. The Supreme Court ultimately affirmed the dismissal of the complaint, ruling that the government had the power to enact and enforce the regulations in question. ==Analysis== The FCC's authority stemmed from its organic statute, the [[Communications Act of 1934]]. The Act provided that:
It is the purpose of this Act, among other things, to maintain the control of the United States over all the channels of interstate and foreign radio transmission; and to provide for the use of such channels, but not the ownership thereof, by persons for limited periods of time, under licenses granted by Federal authority, and no such license shall be construed to create any right, beyond the terms, conditions, and periods of the license.
The Act also provided that the criterion governing the exercise of the Commission's license power is the "public interest, convenience, or necessity." NBC argued that the FCC's power was limited to the technical aspects of radio transmission. The Court found that it was not, but instead "we are asked to regard the Commission as a kind of traffic officer, policing the wave lengths to prevent stations from interfering with each other." NBC argued that the Act did not explicitly allow the Commission to develop regulations for chain broadcasting. The Court admitted this, but held that an explicit grant of power was not necessary in this context, because the field was new and dynamic, and that by granting power to the FCC, it intended "not niggardly but expansive powers." NBC argued that the grant of power to the FCC was unconstitutionally vague, because it did not provide definite guidelines. The Court found that the guidelines were the service of "public interest, convenience, or necessity," and that those guidelines were constitutionally sufficient. The Court concluded that the Chain Broadcasting Regulations were simply the particularization of the Commission's conception of the "public interest" sought to be safeguarded by Congress in enacting the Communications Act. ==Context== The Opinion of the Supreme Court was not unanimous and it led to a conflict with an earlier decision in ''Federal Communications Commission v. Sanders Brothers Radio Station. 309 U.S. 470'' on March 25, 1940. In ''Sanders Brothers'', the FCC interpreted Supreme Court decisions concerning broadcasting to mean that potential economic injury to an existing licensee was not grounds for refusing to license a competitor. (This FCC interpretation remained in place from 1940 to 1958.) The Opinion of the Supreme Court was delivered by [[Felix Frankfurter]] with Justices [[Hugo Black]] and Rutledge taking no part in the discussion or decision. Justice Murphy offered a dissenting Opinion by stating that the Court was effectively giving the FCC a power to regulate networks which had not been given to the FCC by Congress. Murphy stated that;
''... we exceed our competence when we gratuitously bestow upon an agency power which the Congress has not granted. Since that is what the Court in substance does today, I dissent.''
The decision effectively gave the FCC power to regulate the networks. As a result of this 1943 decision, NBC was forced to sell one of its networks and it was this action which then led to the creation of the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC). ==See also== * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 319]] ==External links== *{{wikisource-inline|National Broadcasting Company v. United States (319 U.S. 190)}} *{{note|citation}}{{caselaw source | case = ''National Broadcasting Co. v. United States'', {{ussc|319|190|1943|el=no}} | cornell =https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/319/190 | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/103835/nat-broadcasting-co-v-united-states/ | findlaw = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/319/190.html | googlescholar = https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11254761392460211230 | justia =https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/319/190/case.html | loc =http://cdn.loc.gov/service/ll/usrep/usrep319/usrep319190/usrep319190.pdf }} [[Category:1943 in United States case law]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases of the Stone Court]] [[Category:United States administrative case law]] [[Category:Federal Communications Commission litigation]] [[Category:Broadcast law]] [[Category:NBC Radio Network]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox event |title="Nasty woman" |image=File:Women's March, January 21 2017, Chicago (31601577104).jpg |caption=Demonstrator holding "nasty woman" sign at Women's March, Chicago, January 2017 |date=October 19, 2016<ref name=TG/> |time= |place=[[United States]] |coordinates= |cause=2016 United States presidential debate |url= |casualties1= |casualties2= |website= }} "'''Nasty woman'''" was a phrase used by 2016 American presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]] referring to opponent [[Hillary Clinton]] during the third presidential debate.<ref name=TG>{{cite web|title='Nasty woman': Trump attacks Clinton during final debate|author=Woolf, Nicky|date=October 20, 2016|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/oct/20/nasty-woman-donald-trump-hillary-clinton|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nytlive.nytimes.com/womenintheworld/2017/01/23/nasty-woman-poem-performed-by-ashley-judd-at-womens-march-written-by-19-year-old-nina-donovan/|work=[[The New York Times]]|title='Nasty Woman' poem performed by Ashley Judd at Women's March written by 19-year-old Nina Donovan|author=WITW Staff|date=January 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefederalist.com/2016/10/25/13-times-hillary-clinton-truly-nasty-woman/|work=[[The Federalist (website)|The Federalist]]|title=13 Times Hillary Clinton Was A Truly 'Nasty Woman'|author=Payton, Bre|date=October 25, 2016}}</ref> The phrase made worldwide news and became a viral call for some women voters and has also launched a [[Nasty Woman Movement|feminist movement by the same name]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/nasty-woman-became-a-call-of-solidarity-for-women-voters_us_5808f6a8e4b02444efa20c92|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|title=How 'Nasty Woman' Became A Viral Call For Solidarity|author=Gray, Emma|date=October 20, 2016}}</ref>
The phrase influenced [[Internet meme|memes]],<ref>{{cite web|title=#MemeOfTheWeek: Nasty Woman, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton And Janet Jackson|date=October 20, 2016|author=Sanders, Sam|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/20/498729702/-memeoftheweek-nasty-woman-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-and-janet-jackson|publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Goldman, Nate|date=October 20, 2016|title=Presenting The Best Memes Of The Third Presidential Debate|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/best-memes-third-presidential-debate/|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=The New York Times|title=How Pepe the Frog and Nasty Woman Are Shaping the Election|author=Williams, Alex|date=October 28, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/30/style/know-your-meme-pepe-the-frog-nasty-woman-presidential-election.html}}</ref> popular culture,<ref>{{cite web|title=Jessica Chastain's 'Miss Sloan' Echoes Campaign Rhetoric|date=November 20, 2016|author=Fretts, Bruce|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/21/movies/jessica-chastains-miss-sloane-echoes-campaign-rhetoric.html|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Madonna and Hillary: 'Witch' and 'Nasty Woman' as Sisters in Arms|author=Ganz, Caryn|author2=Healy, Patrick|date=December 11, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/11/arts/music/madonna-hillary-clinton-renegades.html|work=The New York Times}}</ref> books and magazines,<ref name="eve-13mar2017">{{cite news|last1=Murray|first1=Georgia|title=Nasty Women, this new book is for you|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/books/nasty-women-this-new-book-is-for-you-a3488041.html|accessdate=March 24,
